item.title: Why Thailand’s Ruling Political Clan Faces a New Threat
item.description: Thailand’s most prominent political dynasty is on the brink of losing power once again. Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra is facing street protests and growing calls to resign amid mounting anger over a leaked phone call with former Cambodian leader Hun Sen, in which she criticized the Thai army for its role in a border dispute with the neighboring country.
item.dc:creator: Patpicha Tanakasempipat

media:content.media:description: Thailand's Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra Photographer: Nhac Nguyen/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Trump Allowed to Keep Using National Guard in LA for Now
item.description: President Donald Trump can continue to use National Guard troops to respond to protests in Los Angeles as a legal challenge over his use of the military proceeds, a federal appeals court ruled.
item.dc:creator: Madlin Mekelburg

media:content.media:description: Members of the California National Guard stand watch in Los Angeles on June 17.

item.title: China Sends Warplanes Near Taiwan After US Lawmakers’ Visit
item.description: China sent the most warplanes toward Taiwan since October, a move that follows US lawmakers visiting a top military figure and both the UK and Japan sailing warships through the strait separating the island from the Chinese mainland.
item.dc:creator: Yian Lee

item.title: Fidelity Fund Bets on Midcaps Saying Tariff Shock Is Over
item.description: Financial markets have seen the worst of Donald Trump’s tariff threats, helping make midcap stocks an attractive buy as the outlook improves, according to a Fidelity International money manager.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Carson

item.title: Political Woes Threaten to Sink Thai Economy Deeper Into Malaise
item.description: Thailand’s sudden descent into a new political crisis threatens an economy that’s already on the brink of a technical recession and bracing for the impact of the global trade war.
item.dc:creator: Suttinee Yuvejwattana, Claire Jiao

media:content.media:description: Paetongtarn Shinawatra at a news conference in Bangkok on June 19. Photographer: Valeria Mongelli/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump Set to Decide Within Two Weeks Whether to Strike Iran
item.description: President Donald Trump will decide within two weeks whether to strike Iran, his spokeswoman said, as Israel hit more Iranian nuclear sites and warned its attacks may bring down the leadership in Tehran.
item.dc:creator: Akayla Gardner, Alisa Odenheimer, Eltaf Najafizada

media:content.media:description: A firefighter walks past damage at Soroka Medical Center in Beersheba, Israel, on June 19. Photographer: Leo Correa/AP Photo

item.title: Malaysia Court Discharges Najib From One of His 1MDB Cases
item.description: Former Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak succeeded in setting aside another one of his court cases involving troubled state fund 1MDB, in a rare victory for the jailed politician.
item.dc:creator: Kok Leong Chan, Anisah Shukry

media:content.media:description: Najib Razak in 2020. Photographer: Samsul Said/Bloomberg

item.title: Social Media Ban Moves Closer in Australia After Tech Trial
item.description: Australia’s world-first social media ban for under-16s moved closer to implementation after a key trial found that checking a user’s age is technologically possible and can be integrated into existing services.
item.dc:creator: Angus Whitley

media:content.media:description: A focused view of individual's hands using a mobile phone indoors, conveying technology and communication concepts.

item.title: Thai Leader’s Fate Hangs in Balance as Allies Weigh Future
item.description: The political fate of Thai Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra remains uncertain on Friday as the opposition and nationalist groups continue to pile pressure on her to quit following a leaked phone call in which she criticized her army.
item.dc:creator: Patpicha Tanakasempipat

media:content.media:description: Paetongtarn Shinawatra arrives for a news conference in Bangkok, on June 19. Photographer: Valeria Mongelli/Bloomberg

item.title: Xi Shows No Sign of Rescuing Iran as Trump Ramps Up Pressure
item.description: China was quick to condemn Israel after its assault against Iran. Yet President Xi Jinping has shown no sign of rushing to provide weapons and other support that would help Tehran face its most critical military test in decades.
item.dc:creator: Jenni Marsh

item.title: UK Consumer Confidence Rises, Extending a ‘Fragile’ Rebound
item.description: The confidence of UK consumers improved for a second straight month, a survey found, extending a rebound that’s at risk of being derailed as war in the Middle East and higher oil prices cloud the economic outlook.
item.dc:creator: Irina Anghel

item.title: Can the UK Afford to Defend Itself Anymore?
item.description: Caught between a revanchist Russia, US isolationism and a domestic budget dilemma, Britain faces grim choices when it comes to reconstituting its military.
item.dc:creator: Edwina Otira

item.title: EU’s Dombrovskis Says ‘Making Progress’ in Trade Talks With US
item.description: The European Union is continuing intensive trade talks with the US ahead of a July 9 tariff deadline set by President Donald Trump and is “making progress,” according to EU Economy Commissioner Valdis Dombrovskis.
item.dc:creator: Kamil Kowalcze, Michal Kubala

media:content.media:description: Valdis Dombrovskis, economy commissioner for the European Union (EU), during a news conference following a Eurogroup meeting in Luxembourg, on Thursday, June 19, 2025. The Eurogroup is about to kick off its search for a new president, with Paschal Donohoeseen on track to win a third term, a feat that would make the Irishman the second-longest-serving chair of the euro zones finance-chief meetings.

item.title: Lula Says He’s Up For Reelection If Healthy, Will Beat Far-Right
item.description: Brazilian President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva insisted that he will run for reelection next year provided he remains healthy, pledging to block the far-right from regaining power in Latin America’s largest nation.
item.dc:creator: Felipe Saturnino

media:content.media:description: Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva, Brazil’s president, in Paris, France, on Thursday, June 5, 2025

item.title: Maduro Locks Up Economists Sharing Data on Venezuela’s Decline
item.description: President Nicolás Maduro has intensified his crackdown on independent economists and consultants, detaining at least eight people in what critics call a bid to control data exposing Venezuela’s decline.
item.dc:creator: Andreina Itriago, Patricia Laya

media:content.media:description: A man passes a foreign-exchange themed mural in Caracas on June 2. The widening gap between the official and black-market rates threatens to fuel inflation.

item.title: Why Everyone in Washington Is Talking About the Congressional Budget Office
item.description: On today’s Big Take: the Director of the Congressional Budget Office on churning out economic forecasts from inside the center of a political storm.
item.dc:creator: Saleha Mohsin, Rachael Lewis-Krisky

media:content.media:description: Phillip Swagel Photographer: Al Drago/Bloomberg

item.title: Banks in France Face €5 Billion Dividend Tax Bill, Senator Says
item.description: Banks in France are facing a combined tax bill of as much as €5 billion ($5.7 billion) over contentious trades that local authorities say were designed to escape levies on dividend payments, according to a lawmaker.
item.dc:creator: Claudia Cohen, Gaspard Sebag

media:content.media:description: Stock prices.

item.title: Spain Gets New Powers Over Visas, Residence Permits in Gibraltar
item.description: The European Union and UK agreed to give Spain new powers over the issuance of residency permits, visas and asylum in Gibraltar, as part of an accord to settle the post-Brexit border arrangements for the British overseas territory.
item.dc:creator: Jorge Valero, Ellen Milligan

media:content.media:description: Vehicles cross the border from Spain into the British territory of Gibraltar , in la Linea de la Concepcion, southern Spain, on June 12, 2025. The European Union announced on June 11, 2025, that it had sealed a deal with Britain on the status of the territory of Gibraltar, five years after Brexit. (Photo by JORGE GUERRERO / AFP) (Photo by JORGE GUERRERO/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Iran Shuts Down Internet in Bid to Tackle Mounting Cyber Attacks
item.description: Iran imposed a nationwide internet and telephone blackout, telling civilians it’s necessary to prevent Israeli cyber attacks as fears grow the US will join the ongoing conflict.
item.dc:creator: Golnar Motevalli

media:content.media:description: Smoke plumes billow following an overnight Israeli strike on Tehran on June 17, 2025. (Photo by ATTA KENARE / AFP) (Photo by ATTA KENARE/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Qatar Weighs $3.5 Billion Tourism Deal on Egypt’s Med Coast
item.description: Qatar is in advanced talks to invest $3.5 billion in a tourism project on Egypt’s Mediterranean coast, the latest potential Gulf backing for the North African nation’s economy that’s been roiled by regional conflict.
item.dc:creator: Mirette Magdy

media:content.media:description: The north Mediterranean coast, Egypt.

item.title: Indonesia’s Prabowo Embraces Russia, Skipping G-7 for Putin
item.description: Indonesian President Prabowo Subianto pledged to strengthen relations with Russia at a meeting with his Russian counterpart Vladimir Putin.
item.dc:creator: Chandra Asmara, Henry Meyer

media:content.media:description: Vladimir Putin, right, and Prabowo Subianto in St. Petersburg on June 19, in a photo released by Russian state media.

item.title: UN Atomic Body Denies It Gave Israel Cover For Iran Strikes
item.description: The chief of the United Nations atomic watchdog rejected Iranian allegations that a recent nuclear-inspections report, which determined Tehran is in breach of its legal obligations, “in any way” justified Israel’s attacks on the Islamic Republic.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Tirone

media:content.media:description: Rafael Grossi, Director General of the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) at the agency's headquarters in Vienna, Austria on June 16.

item.title: Thiam Party Forms Alliance With Ex-President Before Ivorian Vote
item.description: Parties led by former Credit Suisse AG Chief Executive Officer Tidjane Thiam and ex-President Laurent Gbagbo agreed to form at alliance after both men were excluded from competing in October elections.
item.dc:creator: Kamailoudini Tagba

media:content.media:description: Former Credit Suisse AG Chief Executive Officer Tidjane Thiam, left, and ex-President Laurent Gbagbo

item.title: Africa Battles to Halt Cholera Cases as Funding Cuts Hurt
item.description: Health-funding cuts are wreaking havoc on many African countries’ ability to gain control diseases such as cholera, according to the continent’s main health-advisory body.
item.dc:creator: Janice Kew

media:content.media:description: LUSAKA, ZAMBIA - FEBRUARY 24: Women and children collect water from a water tank provided by the government to provide safe water on February 24, 2024 in Lusaka, Zambia. Cholera, a waterborne bacterial disease, has unleashed a perilous wave across southern Africa, with active outbreaks currently afflicting five countries in southern and central Africa. Over the past two years, the epidemic has left a devastating trail, infecting more than 220,000 individuals, and claiming the lives of over 4,000 people in 19 countries across the continent. Public health experts attribute the widespread devastation to a confluence of factors, including increasingly intense storms driven by climate change, a shortage of vaccines, and inadequate water and sewer infrastructure. Among the affected nations, Zambia stands as one of the hardest hit, grappling with its deadliest cholera outbreak on record. Since October, the country has witnessed over 700 fatalities and more than 18,500 infections, although cases and deaths have shown signs of slowing since their peak in January. (Photo by Luke Dray/Getty Images)

item.title: Denmark to Push Tougher EU Immigration Rules During Presidency
item.description: Denmark will make stricter immigration a top priority for the European Union during its rotating presidency, seeking to use its hard-line stance on migration as a model for the bloc.
item.dc:creator: Sanne Wass

media:content.media:description: Denmark's Minister for European Affairs Marie Bjerre holds a press conference on Denmark's priorities for the EU presidency in the Landsting Hall at the Parliament, Christiansborg in Copenhagen, on June 19, 2025. Denmark takes over the EU presidency from Poland on July 1, 2025. (Photo by Liselotte Sabroe / Ritzau Scanpix / AFP) / Denmark OUT (Photo by LISELOTTE SABROE/Ritzau Scanpix/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Spain Opposes Plan to Raise NATO’s Spending Target to 5%
item.description: Spain will oppose NATO plans to raise the target for members’ defense spending to 5% of GDP, potentially setting up a clash with US President Donald Trump, who wants Europe to spend more on its own security.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Basteiro, Andrea Palasciano

media:content.media:description: Mark Rutte Photographer: Simon Wohlfahrt/Bloomberg

item.title: UK Talks to Administrators in Case Thames Is Nationalized
item.description: The UK has been talking to administrators about next steps for Thames Water as it intensifies preparations for a possible form of temporary nationalization, according to people familiar with the matter, who spoke on the condition of anonymity.
item.dc:creator: Priscila Azevedo Rocha, Giulia Morpurgo

media:content.media:description: A Thames Water works site in London.

item.title: Starmer Urges US Not to Give Up on Diplomatic Path With Iran
item.description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer called on President Donald Trump to keep the door open to talks over Iran’s nuclear program, in the clearest sign yet of the UK leader’s concern about possible American military action against the country.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Milligan, Alex Wickham

media:content.media:description: Heavy traffic in Tehran on June 15.

item.title: Eurogroup Chief Search Kicks Off With Donohoe in Prime Position
item.description: The Eurogroup is about to kick off its search for a new president, with Paschal Donohoe seen on track to win a third term, a feat that would make the Irishman the second-longest-serving chair of the euro zone’s finance-chief meetings.
item.dc:creator: Viktoria Dendrinou, Daniel Basteiro, Kamil Kowalcze, Michal Kubala

media:content.media:description: Paschal Donohoe, president of Eurogroup, during a news conference following a Eurogroup meeting in Brussels, Belgium, on Monday, May 12, 2025. With the euro charting a course for its best year in two decades and asset managers like Amundi SA flipping from bear to bull, Europe's currency is undergoing a resurgence that's rarely been seen at any point since its creation in 1999. Photographer: Simon Wohlfahrt/Bloomberg

item.title: Three Rate Cuts in 24 Hours Show Europe’s Tariff Challenges
item.description: Three interest-rate cuts in just over 24 hours by central banks in Europe highlighted a shift as monetary officials seek to manage the fallout from Donald Trump’s unpredictable trade policies.
item.dc:creator: Zoe Schneeweiss, Ott Ummelas
